title: 'Mamma Mia!' Alumni Reunite as ABBA Musical Returns to Broadway for Limited Run: 'An Incredibly Special Night' (Exclusive)
description: “Mamma Mia!” is back on Broadway — and more than 85 alumni from the musical’s original run reunited to celebrate the limited summer engagement ahead of its official opening on Aug. 14.
content:

Here they go again!

 Mamma Mia! returned to Broadway over the weekend, and some of the ABBA musical's former family were back to say "thank you for the music."

On Friday, Aug. 1, alumni from the Mamma Mia 's fourteen years on Broadway — including members of the cast, creative team, stage and company management — gathered together for an invited dress rehearsal.

 Never miss a story — sign up for to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. 

The event began with a pre-show cocktail reception at Winnie’s Broadway in New York City, where the alums reconnected and reminisced. They then headed to the Winter Garden Theatre for a performance a source on the scene tells PEOPLE was nothing short of "electric."

"It was an incredibly special night" the insider says. "Alumni in the audience danced and jived and had the time of their lives while watching Mamma Mia 's current company on stage for the first time. It called to mind a high school reunion in many ways! There was so much love in that room."

Among the more than 85 actors in attendance were Frankie Grande, Dee Hoty, Alison Luff, Courtney Reed, Raymond J. Lee and original cast members Judy Kaye, Karen Mason, Tonya Doran, Janet Rothermel, Jon-Erik Goldberg, Meghann Dreyfuss, Robin Baxter, and Yuka Takara.

They all posed together in the house after the performance, alongside the new Broadway cast.

 Mamma Mia! first premiered in London’s West End in 1999, before transferring to Broadway in 2001.

Directed by Phyllida Lloyd, the musical ran there for 14 years, becoming the ninth longest-running show in Broadway history.

Set on a sunny Greek island, the story — with a book by Catherine Johnson — follows a young bride-to-be who invites three men from her mother’s past in hopes of discovering which one is her father.

All is told through a soundtrack of Swedish pop group ABBA’s greatest hits, including chart-toppers like “Dancing Queen,” “SOS,” “Take a Chance on Me,” “Super Trouper,” “Money, Money, Money,” “Voulez-Vous,” “Knowing Me, Knowing You,” “Lay All Your Love on Me,” “Thank You for the Music,” “The Winner Takes It All” and the title track, “Mamma Mia.”

The musical has spawned two hit movie adaptations: 2008’s Mamma Mia! and 2018’s Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again . The star-studded cast includes Meryl Streep, Amanda Seyfried, Pierce Brosnan, Colin Firth, Stellan Skarsgård, Christine Baranski, Julie Walters, Dominic Cooper, Lily James and Cher.

Broadway audiences can catch Mamma Mia! for a limited six-month-only engagement through Feb. 1, 2026. The production, coming from the show's national tour, officially opens on Aug. 14.

Leading the cast is Christine Sherrill (as Donna), Amy Weaver (as Sophie), Carly Sakolove (as Rosie), Jalynn Steele (as Tanya), Rob Marnell (as Harry Bright), Jim Newman (as Bill Austin), Victor Wallace (as Sam Carmichael) and Grant Reynolds (as Sky).

The ensemble includes Lena Owens (as Lisa), Justin Sudderth (as Pepper), Ethan Van Slyke (as Eddie) and Haley Wright (as Ali), as well as Sarah Agrusa, Alessandra Antonelli, Caro Daye Attayek, Adia Olanethia Bell, Emily Croft, Madison Deadman, Andy Garcia, Jordan De Leon, Nico DiPrimio, Patrick Dunn, Danny Lopez-Alicea, Makoa, Erica Mansfield, Jasmine Overbaugh, Gray Phillips, Blake Price, Dorian Quinn and Xavi Soto Burgos.

Out of the 30 in the cast, 25 are making their Broadway debut.

 Tickets for  are now on sale.
summary: Mamma Mia! the ABBA musical returned to Broadway for a limited run on August 1, with alumni from its 14-year run on Broadway, including members of the cast, creative team, stage and company management, gathered for an event called "An Incredibly Special Night." The event began with a pre-show cocktail reception at Winnie's Broadway in New York City, where the alums reunited for a performance at the Winter Garden Theatre. The event was described as "an incredibly special night" by a source on the scene. Mamma Mia!, first premiered in London's West End in 1999, before transferring to Broadway in 2001, and ran there for 14 years, becoming the ninth longest-running show in Broadway history. The musical has spawned two hit movie adaptations: 2008’s Mammama Mia.
shortSummary: Mamma Mia! returned to Broadway for a limited run this summer, with alums reuniting for a dress rehearsal and subsequent performances, marking an event attended by 85 alums.

scraped_sources.text: Broadway Legends Unite to Celebrate 50th Anniversary of Landmark Musical, A Chorus Line (Exclusive Photos) Go inside the one-night-only concert with PEOPLE By Dave Quinn Dave Quinn Dave Quinn is the Deputy News Director at PEOPLE. He has been working at the brand since 2016, and is the author of the No. 1 New York Times best-selling book, Not All Diamonds and Rosé: The Inside Story of the Real Housewives from the People Who Lived It. People Editorial Guidelines Published on July 28, 2025 04:50PM EDT 1 Comment Credit : Jenny Anderson NEED TO KNOW A Chorus Line celebrated its 50th anniversary with a star-studded concert at Broadway's Shubert TheatreOriginal cast member Baayork Lee directed the event, featuring songs like “What I Did for Love” and “One”Ariana DeBose, Annette Bening, Lauren Graham, Bebe Neuwirth and more took the stage to honor the iconic musical It was a singular sensational evening in New York City on Sunday, July 27, as a slew of Broadway legends united to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the landmark musical, A Chorus Line — and PEOPLE has an exclusive look behind the curtain. The concert benefit, which raised money for the Entertainment Community Fund, took place at the Shubert Theatre, where A Chorus Line opened on Broadway five decades earlier (on July 25, 1975). Baayork Lee, one of the Pulitzer Prize-winning musical's original stars, directed the event (dubbed A Chorus Line Official 50th Anniversary Celebration). A Tony Award honoree, Lee has been the primary steward of A Chorus Line since its creation, overseeing nearly every major production of the musical since. For the celebration, she remounted the original choreography Michael Bennett and Bob Avian. "It has been an honor to spend the last 50 years of my life bringing A Chorus Line around the world," Lee said. "It warms my heart to celebrate this milestone at our original home of 15 years, the Shubert Theatre. I know Michael (Bennett) and Bob (Avian) are smiling down knowing their legacy continues on. Here’s to another 50 years." Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. A Chorus Line debuted at The Public Theater in 1975 before transferring to Broadway, where it became an instant sensation. Conceived and directed by Bennett — with music by Marvin Hamlisch, lyrics by Edward Kleban and a book by James Kirkwood Jr. and Nicholas Dante — the groundbreaking musical pulled back the curtain on the lives of Broadway dancers, using real-life stories shared during a series of workshops. The original production ran for a then-record-breaking 6,137 performances over 15 years, becoming the longest-running show in Broadway history at the time. It won nine Tonys including Best Musical, as well as the Pulitzer Prize for Drama. A 1985 film adaptation and a 2006 Broadway revival helped cement the show as a landmark of American musical theater. Sunday's event honored A Chorus Line's legacy, with performances from the score including beloved songs like "What I Did for Love," "At the Ballet," "The Music and the Mirror" and the signature show-stopping finale, "One." Among the stars were Lee's fellow O.G. cast members Kelly Bishop, Wayne Cilento, Priscilla Lopez and Donna McKechnie. Special performances throughout the evening came from Charlotte d'Amboise, Annette Bening, Tommy Bracco, Ariana DeBose, Jessica Lee Goldyn, Mandy Gonzalez, Lauren Graham, Robyn Hurder, Francis Jue, Bebe Neuwirth, Brad Oscar, Krysta Rodriguez, Jennifer Simard, Jessica Vosk, Anthony Wayne, Tony Yazbeck and Leigh Zimmerman. Among those in the dance ensemble? Nick Adams, Ruby Calamia, Lauren Celentano, Brandon Burks, Sara Esty, Jessica Lee Goldyn, Eddie Gutierrez, Fiona Claire Huber, Konnor Kelly, Ian Liberto, Pierre Marais, Drew Minard, Adriana Negron, Bethany Ann Tesarck, Caleb Marshall Villarreal and Blake Zelesnikar. Photographer Jenny Anderson snapped many of the stars behind the scenes. argos_summary: Mamma Mia! made its return to Broadway with a special dress rehearsal attended by over 85 alumni from its 14-year run, celebrating the musical's legacy and reconnecting with the current cast. The event featured a cocktail reception followed by a performance at the Winter Garden Theatre, described as 'electric' by attendees. The musical, which first premiered in London in 1999 and transferred to Broadway in 2001, is known for its ABBA soundtrack and has inspired two successful film adaptations.
